summary:
My medical and scientific career started in 1977 when I became a cardiologist in the Wilhelmina Gasthuis in Amsterdam. Between 1979 and 1981 I worked in the cardiology department in the Binnen Gasthuis. In June 1981 we moved to the new Academic Medical Center. I worked there at the department of Cardiology, where I fulfilled many different roles, from chief of the Coronary Care Unit,chief of the Emergency Cardiac Care unit,  chief of the Catheterization laboratory and supervisor of the consultation service. I followed training and practiced intervention cardiology and implantation of cardiac devices (pacemakers and implantable cardioverter-defibrillators, ICD's).
At the same time my research focussed on emergency cardiac care: prevention of ventricular fibrillation by anti arrhythmic drugs (the subject of my PhD thesis). After that my research centered on management of out-of-hospital cardiac arrest (OHCA). A registry started in 1995 which has recorded and analyses OHCA on an intense and uninterrupted basis since 2005: the ARREST (AmsteRdam REsuscitation STudies) study. A large intervention study of benefit of automated external defibrillators (AED's) was performed between 2000 and 2002. Ever since, I promoted and followed the introduction of AEDs, which was very successful. Introduction first was with police and fire fighters first responders, since 2009 also intensely in residential communities.
Our research group continuously engages in new research projects on OHCA. In association with Hanno Tan MD, PhD as co-PI (who received funding from the EU Horizon 2020 program with the program Escape-NET) and Marieke Blom, PhD as senior researcher there are now 7 PhD students and 5 data managers active in the ARREST group. 
I retired from the cardiology practice in 2014 but since then dedicate much of my time to the study of OHCA through the ARREST study, which I hope to continue several years to come.
